author: @Hannal-hn6ch
text: Hi Dr. Starmer, I really enjoy your videos and the book you wrote! It's the most often read book on my shelf. I have one question in the mice example in this video. The small p value tells us there is a significant difference between the models with and without weight/mutant or not/.etc. But can you conclude which model is better? I found this is confusing for me. I look forward to your reply!

author: @jamah3842
text: I am very confused by the contrast coefficients in ANOVA, would be great if StatQuest can do a video on this!

author: @kasperfischer-rasmussen8253
text: Hey Josh and than you for your incredbile videos! I was wondering if you are going to make a video explaining mixed models with fixed vs. random effects? Fx how this differs from just including grouping factors as fixed effects. This could perhaps be coupled with an introduction to the lmer4 package in R? Keep up the good work, it is much appreciated!

author: @jamesly__vi1di
text: Hello Josh, first I want to thank you for putting these videos on YouTube. You are a great teacher. I have a question tho. In your explanation of lm() |> summary(), you skipped what values in the (Intercept) row mean. I saw other data scientists just ignore values in the (Intercept) row but I don't know what they mean and why we are ignoring those values...

author: @zacharybrecheisen2601
text: I've been trying to figure out how to structure pre-planned contrasts (e.g. contrast matrices) in R rather than relying on post-hoc tests like Tukey, but I have been largely stumped in terms of how to actually get them to work in R. Do you have any pointers or advice?

author: @kushalbhattacharya4011
text: Anyway its not the design matrix what comes from the theory.....its the design matrix coming from the dummy variable regression technique.  Kindly if possible make a video to show how to get the design matrix for a ANOVA or ANCOVA model by not dropping any column.

author: @simonbaum3025
text: Explained so well! I am really impressed how you can break down that material in something so easy to follow. Please keep that up. I have one naive question. I guess for the models it would not matter if we add instead of 0 and 1, lets say 1 and 2 into the design matrix?

author: @dmitryfalkov4334
text: Great video!  The best stat resource in the net!  Thank you a lot, Josh! one short question. It looks like when we remove "TypeMutant" from the model then we already deal with "Lab A mean" but not with "Lab A CONTROL mean" (e.g. see 7:35 - 7:40) , since we have no difference between groups in the lab. Is it true?

author: @elainelyu6875
text: I know this might be a stupid question, but I am recently learning multi-level modelling, and when I look at the first example, it feels like I can also apply a two-level random intercept model if I consider each mouse as Level 1 and the mutant/control condition as Level 2. So what's the difference between this approach and multilevel modelling? Can I apply two-level modelling here and why? Thanks!

author: @savvaskefalas5635
text: maybe this time i will manage to communicate my misunderstanding with r Code.Thnx a lot.Why is valid345 false (the 3:45 is time in video) modelfancy<-lm(Size~Type+Weight)               pvalfancy=0.00367 notthelastpval=0.00256 modelnoiweight<-lm(Size~Type)               pvalnoweight=0.1964 differenceAt345thefancyequationfitsthedatathanifweremovedtheweightparameter=pvalnoweight-pvalfancy valid345=  differenceAt345thefancyequationfitsthedatathanifweremovedtheweightparameter==notthelastpval
